body:
Independent news website AmmonNews published a statement from Jordanian tribal leaders criticizing policies of the King and government last Sunday.  According to an AmmonNews statement, shortly thereafter hackers removed the article, took down the news site, and accessed editorial email accounts.  The Jordan Press Association then demanded an investigation into the turn of events, and Ammon staff members held a protest outside the assocation. 

In Jordan's blogosphere and Twitter conversations, reactions were mixed.  Laith Abbadi tweeted in the midst of AmmonNews' shutdown:



 We want #ammonnews back where are you? who is blocking you? #JO #Jordan

Farrah Mufleh warned the attackers that the message of the letter would continue despite the shutdown:


 Shutting down @AmmonNewsAr does not mean every1 is going to magically forget the letter.. #FAILL #JO


Others were skeptical.  Nadine Toukan wrote:




 So what did the alleged hacking story turn out to be in the end? #JO drama behind the drama!


Naseem Tarawnah posted a blog entry describing the timeline of the events, concluding:



 Now whether this was a genuine attack by authorities, by fervent technologically capable citizens, or simply a sensationalist attempt by Ammon itself, is unknown at the moment, but I do hope it not the former.

Others directly accused AmmonNews of concocting the story.  Mahmoud Lattouf tweeted:



 Does anyone buy Ammon claims that their site has been hacked? I think it's nonsense! #Jordan #Jo

While Maan commented on Tarawnah's post:


 I think Ammon want to create a reputation as an ‘oppressed’ news portal in a very ripe time…well, any reputation is a reputation at the end of the day, so I give that to them at least.



Jordan's government is not known for direct shutdowns of independent news sites.  King Abdullah II has repeatedly affirmed rights of the press, but the government has closed offices for Iranian-based media outlets, and the vast majority of reporters indicate that they practice self-censorship in their work.  An official investigation has not yet been announced.

Independent news website AmmonNews published a statement from Jordanian tribal leaders criticizing policies of the King and government last Sunday. According to an AmmonNews statement, shortly thereafter hackers removed the article, took down the news site, and accessed editorial email accounts. The Jordan Press Association then demanded an investigation into the turn of events, and Ammon staff members held a protest outside the assocation. In Jordan's blogosphere and Twitter conversations, reactions were mixed. Laith Abbadi tweeted in the midst of AmmonNews' shutdown:
We want #ammonnews back where are you? who is blocking you? #JO #Jordan
Farrah Mufleh warned the attackers that the message of the letter would continue despite the shutdown:
Shutting down @AmmonNewsAr does not mean every1 is going to magically forget the letter.. #FAILL #JO
Others were skeptical. Nadine Toukan wrote:
So what did the alleged hacking story turn out to be in the end? #JO drama behind the drama!
Naseem Tarawnah posted a blog entry describing the timeline of the events, concluding:
Now whether this was a genuine attack by authorities, by fervent technologically capable citizens, or simply a sensationalist attempt by Ammon itself, is unknown at the moment, but I do hope it not the former.
Others directly accused AmmonNews of concocting the story. Mahmoud Lattouf tweeted:

While Maan commented on Tarawnah's post:

King Abdullah II has repeatedly affirmed rights of the press, but the government has closed offices for Iranian-based media outlets, and the vast majority of reporters indicate that they practice self-censorship in their work. An official investigation has not yet been announced.
title: Jordan: News Site Hacked?

According to an AmmonNews statement, shortly thereafter hackers removed the article, took down the news site, and accessed editorial email accounts.
The Jordan Press Association then demanded an investigation into the turn of events, and Ammon staff members held a protest outside the assocation.
In Jordan's blogosphere and Twitter conversations, reactions were mixed.

Laith Abbadi tweeted in the midst of AmmonNews' shutdown:

who is blocking you? #JO #Jordan

King Abdullah II has repeatedly affirmed rights of the press, but the government has closed offices for Iranian-based media outlets, and the vast majority of reporters indicate that they practice self-censorship in their work.
An official investigation has not yet been announced.
